comments.html: The RPF check for IP multicast routers does not forward packets received on interfaces that do not lead to the source address. Thus packets with source address 0.0.0.0 can only be accepted from an interface that a default route points to, if at all. This should not lead to a forwarding loop.
comments.name: Erik Auerswald

comments.html: In addition to multicast RPF, an invalid source address would make it impossible for IP multicast routers to join the multicast SPT tree towards the source (either directly in case of SSM or as an intermediate phase via RP in case of ASM), breaking the whole idea of how multicast distribution trees are signalled and how they work.
